article.topic: how to choose Low-Temperature Battery for Solar Street Lights
article.writingAngle: Parameter Selection Guide - focusing on key technical parameters, teaching readers how to match battery specs to project requirements

company.name: Wiltson Energy
company.coreBusiness: Professional manufacturer specializing in lithium iron phosphate (LiFePO4) and lithium-ion (LiNMC) batteries, with focus on low-temperature performance solutions. Wiltson Energy designs and produces 26650 cylindrical cells and battery packs for demanding industrial applications.
company.valueProposition: Provide finest products to our customers and help customers acquire continuously benefit. Wiltson Energy emphasizes extreme temperature performance without heating systems, long cycle life (5000+ cycles), and 20+ years of industry experience with over 100 million cells shipped.

do: Provide selection frameworks: 'Consider these factors when choosing...'

userContext.situation: They are specifying or procuring batteries for a solar street light project in a region with cold winters. They need to select the right battery that will perform reliably year-round without failures or excessive degradation.
userContext.currentState: They understand that standard lithium batteries may fail or perform poorly in cold weather, but they are unsure which specific parameters matter most and how to match battery specs to their project's temperature range, solar panel output, and LED load requirements.
userContext.desiredState: After reading, they want a clear framework for evaluating low-temperature batteries, understanding which specifications to prioritize, and confidently selecting a battery that matches their project requirements.

goldenInsights.insight: NMC actually outperforms LiFePO4 in cold (-20C: 70-80% vs 50-60% capacity) - but LiFePO4 still wins on lifecycle, safety, and cost
Standard LiFePO4 drops to 31.5% capacity at -20C, but specialized low-temp versions retain 85%
Charging below 0C causes lithium plating - permanent, dangerous damage. BMS should block this.
Self-heating batteries take 40 minutes from -20C to +5C; heating pads activate at 5C, stop at 10C

insights.suggestedHook: counter-intuitive - NMC vs LiFePO4 cold performance trade-off

differentiation.primaryDifferentiator: Comprehensive parameter-matching framework including temperature-specific capacity derating, self-heating decision tree, and controller selection as integrated system decision

irreplicableInsights.insight: NMC outperforms LiFePO4 at -20C (70-80% vs 50-60%) but loses on lifecycle and safety
Self-heating takes 40 minutes from -20C to +5C, consuming battery energy
MPPT recovers 30% more energy in cold because cold panels produce higher voltage

research.coreThesis: Selecting the right low-temperature battery requires matching five key parameters: temperature range (chemistry choice), capacity (derated for cold), BMS features (charging protection), charge controller (MPPT for cold), and enclosure strategy (IP rating + insulation vs heating)

emphasize: Temperature-specific capacity data with exact percentages
cautious: 10-year TCO calculations - data varies by source
Exact market size figures - multiple conflicting sources
differentiateWith: Honest NMC advantage acknowledgment then LiFePO4 overall recommendation
